item.title: Wrong Cyrillic
item.description: Misuse of Cyrillic The letter Я (also the word for I) has nothing to do with an R. And the И/и is an I/i, not an N/n. If it is used that way, then disasters like Яussiaи are the consequences.

item.title: O and A: Tolstoy, Bolshoi and krakadil Gena
item.description: Oh and ah The o is the most common letter in Russian (as mentioned in Paste Sounds ). Were all those o’s to have an o sound, the whole language would have changed sound. Now it has been determined that an unstressed o (usually) sounds like an a, and that was a good idea.

item.title: ш and щ: Spot the Differences
item.description: Sound For what descriptions of sounds are worth: Wikipedia compares ш to ‘sh in shop’ and ‘ch in machine,’ but when it comes to щ, it hits a dead end: ‘Dutch has no words with this sound.’ The English Wikipedia entry for shcha/щ isn’t much help either: ‘it represents the voiceless alveolo-palatal fricative /ɕ(ː)/.

item.title: The letter ы
item.description: Sounds Like An indescribable sound, indeed. But people have tried. Wikipedia loosely describes it as “like the u in bunker” (which is far off). Wikibooks says it’s somewhere between “u” and “j”, while Russisch in Rusland compares it to something between “u” and “i”.

item.title: The letter Ё
item.description: Yo The sound isn’t hard. It’s like the Yo in York, says the (English) Wikipedia . The Dutch version compares it to the jo in jokken (to fib). Russian sources often give examples like ёжик (jozhik, hedgehog) or ёлка (yolka, Christmas tree).

item.title: A Piece of Cake: Russian Alphabet
item.description: Apps Starting simple is recommended. For Android users: Russian alphabet for kids is great for beginners and looks cheerful. You’ll also learn some basic words right away. Russian Alphabet is less about cheerfulness but is clear and practical. Some example words are (too) difficult for beginners.
